comments.commentBody: Look, we can argue the technicality of whether or not the CRT label is actually what is being taught in schools. This newspaper itself sponsored the 1619 project whose initial thesis was that the American Revolution was fought to preserve the institution of slavery. comments.commentBody:
"Democrats probably need a new way to talk about progressive ideology and education."

This is certainly one take on how Democrats can deal with their loss in Virginia.  Another is to take all things equal a year from now - then what should Democrats do?

One answer: *more Democrats could turn out to vote.*

Youngkin (R) received about 1.6 million votes to McAuliffe (D) with about 1.5 million votes - a spread of roughly 100,000 votes.

Assuming a 50% voter turnout for McAuliffe, that leaves about 1.5 million votes on the table for him - and he only lost by 0.1 million votes.  So if he could have picked up roughly 7% of these potential supporters (i.e., Democrats, Independents and Republican crossovers who stayed home this time around), he would have won.

Democrats should consider what just happened in Virginia as a dry run for the midterms next year.  *They need to up Democratic voter turnout - in some regions by as much as 10% or more.*  This may seem a daunting task, but it is doable - albeit with a great deal of effort.

Democrats have the next year to get that done.

The clock is ticking.

For Democrats to win the midterms, they need the votes.  And they must win the midterms, or there will be congressional gridlock into 2024, and that will likely cost Democrats the presidency the next time around.  And that will put the country back in perilous shape with the possible return of a Trump presidency - perhaps coupled with a Congress controlled by the GOP.

comments.commentBody: I teach history in Mississippi.  Over the past year, more and more parents have expressed fear and outrage that "divisive" topics like slavery and Civil Rights are being taught in the schools, and that these topics make children uncomfortable.  Whenever I hear these complaints or concerns, the thought that percolates in the back of my head is, "good."  Slavery and Jim Crow should make you uncomfortable because they are, in fact, uncomfortable.  Learning about the Holocaust should make you uncomfortable because the mass slaughter of millions should shock anyone who is not a sociopath.  To those who object to the teaching of these subjects, I would ask a simple topic:  How should they be taught?  You can say, "Oh, it's the past," but there are many living people who came of age under Jim Crow.  You can say, "Oh, they're aberrations."  But slavery was the cornerstone of the economy and de jure Segregation lasted for anywhere from 50 to 80 years after emancipation.  So please, what's the answer?

replies.commentBody: @MG Maybe the issue isn't *whether* these subjects are taught, but *how* they're taught and what age level is being addressed.  I don't think there's a state curriculum anywhere covering, say 7-12th grades, that doesn't include slavery and Jim Crow.  These topics are everywhere, and have been there for at least 20 years.  The civil rights struggle is *the* driving theme of US history and social studies.  But how is this being taught, and why is that method drawing such intense parental concern?

@historian 
The better question may be why these parents choose to ignore history - bigotry? Ignorance? Racism? All of the above?

I grew up in the lily white suburbs, but my parents were school teachers in an inner city ghetto in the northeast. I would accompany them to their workplaces when I was off from school, often sitting in on their classes. When the subject of slavery was taught, almost all of the kids in the class were interested, were thrilled to hear how their forebearers arrived, lived, worked & died. Many related family stories about the experience of slavery. It was an extremely positive experience for the kids as well as the community as a whole. 

Let's just say it out loud - there is a portion of the US population that embraces a fallacious  narrative - whether it's masking the Civil War as "Northern Aggression" or attributing certain characteristics to racial/religious groups. There is also another portion of the population that abets &/or tolerates it in order to manipulate it for extraneous purposes - political, of course.

Calling prejudice "discomfort" is unacceptable, nothing more than a "big lie". Who's fooling who here, the uneducated or the educated?

@Ajvan1 Perhaps, but I like to remain optimistic about our society, and I tend to believe that people can change, for both better and ill.  One thing that worries me is that many parents are having their worst instincts stoked by political organizations that are using school boards and issues related to education as the latest wedge issue.  To put it another way, I suspect some cynical and opportunistic people with deep pockets are ginning up hatred.

@historian To the extent that these topics are taught [some teachers ignore the guidelines or simply ignore the guidelines], they are taught in a straightforward manner, including with the abundant use of primary sources.  The problem is that parents are increasingly unwilling to have their children learn about these topics.  The right has managed to frame almost any discussion of these topics as CRT.  Some parents want comforting stories about well-treated slaves or white southern moderates or progressives who were always [secretly] pulling for the Freedom Struggle.  In point of fact, both slavery and Jim Crow had the overwhelming support of white citizens and the muscular backing of the state.   Something similar happens in discussions of the Holocaust, where people must confront the truth that majority of people in central and eastern Europe were willing to support the Nazis or at least willing themselves to be ignorant of what was happening.   For every Bonhoeffer, there were dozens of German Christians who happily shot innocent men, women, and children.  These are had facts to confront at any age.

@Tim Africans were not "tribal" in the age of the slave trade.  They lived in complex states with organized political systems, militaries, artistic traditions, and economies that were embedded in economic systems that stretched from the Mediterranean to the Indian Ocean.  Mansa Musa was one of the wealthiest and most influential men of his time.  The Portuguese who encountered West Africans in the fifteenth and sixteenth centuries treated West Africans as political equals and even exchanged ambassadors with some kingdoms.  These kingdoms did engage in wars of expansion, and they did sell captives to European slave traders, but they were simply pursuing a strategy that gave them advantages over their enemies.  Otherwise, great points!

@MG The question isn’t how history is taught in Mississippi, but in Virginia, particularly in blue Northern VA. I went to public school in Fairfax county 40 years ago and was absolutely taught the true history of our country, tragedies and triumphs. The problem is that now, kids are being taught to view everything as tragic and racist, and the Civil Rights movement as a failure.

@Tim  "There was no idea back then that we are all one single (abstract) "human race"-- tribal Africans, based on their behavior, their culture, were clearly inferior to Europeans."

Only in the eyes of the Europeans, sir.

@MG I think (atleast) a sizable number of conservatives would agree that we should be teaching the ugly portions of history. And though it may surprise you, that includes many such as myself who lean hard right. 

By my estimation, we differ in our approach to that learning objective. The novel approach championed by the left requires special note made of how America harmed black people or native americans in every chapter. A process amounting to American self flagellation from which no sense of national pride can emerge alive. Whereas a favorable approach on the right would be to confine the self flagellation to a chapter or two.
@MG You're supposed to do what conservatives want but never come out and say: be quiet and help keep minorities "in their place".

@MG I think this is a bit of a straw man argument. I went to public school in the 1990s and we absolutely were taught about slavery, jim crow, the holocaust, the genocide of native americans, etc. etc. There is a genuinely different thing going on now in certain progressive circles and (as the column points out) we can't pretend it doesn't exist. There's a difference between Ibrahim X. Kendi and learning about jim crow in history class.

@eheck 

Wow! Sixth grade? I can't remember a time I did not know about slavery and Jim Crow. I recall reading about Sojourner Truth with my son in Kindergarten and discussing slavery. He could not wrap his head around it. He kept asking and asking. He was uncomfortable. We are supposed to be

As a 65 year old white man who grew up in suburban New Jersey in the 1960s and attended Catholic parochial school I just want to make the following observation.
I don’t recall ever being “taught” about the Holocaust or even the subject of anti-semitism in anything even approaching depth. 
Nothing! 
Zilch!
The subject and issue of the role of race in WW2 in both Europe and Asia was never really explored in any way. Discussions of racism and the legacy of slavery and territorial conquest in America was barely touched on. The political and cultural upheavals taking place outside schools were our “teachers”. The classroom was where I learned the very superficial outlines of history and geography..and of course…how to read and write and do math.
What I will say was that the overlying mission of elementary school history education was anti-communism. To that end, most “history” education of the period tended to frame the conflicts of the 19th and 20th centuries as conflicts against some form of totalitarianism…even when the actual roots were far more complex. Nuance and critical thinking was not prized. That was reserved for college. The goal of school was to churn out obedient “good citizens”.
BTW…with nuns getting on your case all the time, the whole notion of making kids “comfortable” was not really valued, at least as I recall.
@MG The CRT-ers are the politicos "stoking the worst instincts".

@MG You do it without making white children feel guilty and cry home to their parents that they hate themselves and identity. It needs to be taught but not in a way that it alienates specific groups of young children

@MG If anything, segregation has become more entrenched. Only now it's more subtle and insidious. As Pete Townsend might have said, meet the new racism, same as the old racism. Makes my skin crawl when I read WSJ and people write with a straight face that blacks have same opportunities as the rest of us but choose not to apply themselves.

@MG 
For now the answer is to do what it takes to win elections.

@historian One historian to another, I agree.  I have come to the conclusion that teaching history as authoritative knowledge is the problem.  Even if I agreed with every nuance in a textbook, the medium is the message and textbooks are a lie because history is not authoritative knowledge.  

As I know you already know, history is contested engagement with the past in the present, and academic history is the effort to engage these contests with evidence and argument.

But that's not how we mostly teach it.  

Abolish the textbook.  Check out OUP's "Debating American History" series. The answer is not to pick one side or the other; the answer is to teach the debate, provide primary sources and secondary arguments, and then make the kids take positions and defend them.  I set up the 1619 Project as target practice.  Kids can defend it or attack.  The grade is based on writing, use of evidence, and argument.  

We don't want a right wing textbook, but we don't want a left wing textbook either.

@MG 
Interesting is your observation that this happened “over the past year”. Civil Rights and Slavery have been part of the curriculum (even in Mississippi, I hope) for much longer than that. That parents are complaining just recently shows how effective the GOP strategists are at finding the social/cultural issue du jour and with the help of FOX and other propaganda outlets make it election deciding issues. Case in point, even though I consider myself pretty well read, ‘Critical Race Theory’ was not in my vocabulary until very recently. Look, even if Democrats totally eliminate cultural issues, as worthy as they are, from their platform, the GOP will always find the one or the other to whip up their base, because they have nothing else to run on. Democrats just have to make sure to counter this by delivering on the important issues when they are in power. But if they can’t even convince Manchin to support fining methane leaks, one of the easiest steps to avert global climate catastrophe, they get what they deserve.

@MG precisely why virtual school ended up being a serendipitous arrangement for us.  Middle school is already a tough age but being home with the camera off and muted, allowed my kid to articulate, IN THE MOMENT, his incredulousness and profound grasp of how America came to be. He’s not being disruptive in a classroom setting and can process knowledge.  It’s a chance to talk with his parents about life in America. That’s part of growing up.  It’s just too bad many can’t or won’t see the benefit of allowing ALL this option.  Kids should not have to hold their emotions in or be punished for being a human being who can sympathy AND empathize with the conditions of other both in the past and present.

@MG Part of the problem is that we teach history differently in different parts of the country.  Just look at the textbook analysis done by the NYT last year about how major topics are presented in the California vs. the Texas social studies textbooks.  If we can't agree on how we present and discuss our past, how can we hope to agree on the right way forward?

@MG This is a straw man argument.  Certainly the right overreaches, and tries to ban GOOD things too in response to the left. But many sensible people are truly disgusted by CRT, and it's effects on society, and still want jim crow/slavery taught honestly in schools.  Hard to know where Youngkin is - but certainly McCauliffe gave into the radicals in his party.  Youngkin seemed reasonable in comparison.

@historian 

The how isn't the concern of the people fighting the CRT bogeyman.

The heart of the issue is that few people are OK to be called out as racist whether they profess to be or not, and most people (including those on the left) have trouble conceptually separating "you have benefited from historic injustice" from "you are to blame for said injustice."

Righteous or not, cancel culture and pronoun wars and celebrity trends are scaring the pants off of people who feel like recognition of discriminatory practices means they will face blame for being a beneficiary of that discrimination (however passively that may be), a connection that is demonstrably a threat to their social (public shaming) and financial (getting fired) safety.

@MG  

The Left and Right have had the same divergent educational priorities for decades.  The C.R.T. furor is just old wine in new bottles.

The Left wants educational institutions that teach children to be critical, objective thinkers, so they will learn from our nation's mistakes as well as its successes.

The Right wants nationalistic Sunday schools that teach children to be blindly proud of living in "the greatest country on earth" and profoundly ignorant of its past and present problems.   

Which model do we want?  Schools that teach children to think for themselves, or schools that teach children to be faithful believers?  It stupefies me that the answer to that remains a major polarizing issue in 2021.  

But it very much is.

@MG——Thank you for your excellent comment.  The answer is:  Teach History without sanitizing it.  If it is taught well, it will afflict the comfortable and comfort the afflicted.  The extremists on the left continue to insist that we right the wrongs of the past.  We cannot undo the injustices of the past.  The problem with the movement to require Ethnic Studies as a graduation requirement (which California￼’s governor recently signed into law and is laced with Critical Race Theory), is that students of most backgrounds will be marginalized and feel “less than.”  

Just teach history with all of our warts so our children can grow up with a knowledge and understanding of our past and the hope they will not repeat those glaring acts of inequality that were made by our ancestors.

@MG The truth of the matter is that all of those complaining Mississippi parents would like nothing more than to revert back to Jim Crow or even slavery. We live in an incredibly bigoted society and nothing will ever change that. Hate and greed are what this country was founded on and they are still the driving forces behind U.S. society. That too will never change.

@Matthew The problem is that I am not aware of any teachers who try to make white children feel guilty or embarrassed.  Indeed, I cannot imagine what that would look like in a classroom unless it became something like a theater of the absurd.  "Timmy, you are personally responsible for the enslaved people brought to Jamestown in 1619."  The problem is that we are living in an environment where people are being told that this is happening in the schools, and they react accordingly.

@MG the answer is move on.  We have been discussing these issues since the 1960s.  So many things have changed since then including inclusiveness in the workplace and media.  it's time to move on that's the answer.  I am tired of being beaten over the head with white privilege and everyone who is not a POC is at fault nonsense

@C  You seem to be saying, in effect, that once slavery was over, and the native Americans had been put on reservations, there were no more problems for them, and the rest of American history was simply positive.  But that is simply factually untrue, and to teach history that way is a lie.  I have seen my kid’s’ history textbooks, and if they’re any indication, this whole flap over history teaching is really overblown and politicized.   The books and teachers strike a balance between the many achievements of this country and its failings.

Isn't the point that slavery and Jim Crow have been taught as events that occurred in the past, but the effects and implications of these are woven into current unacceptable truths?  That's not being widely taught, or explained as a perspective.  That racism is alive and well, in overt but also subversive ways, is not being taught. It's more complex than a couple of statements, but to me, it's very important both that we all learn to see that our actions affect others in ways we don't know, and that racist thoughts and actions abide.  The people who are 'intensely concerned' seem either offended - the whole 'but I'M not racist' or 'that was in the past' attitude - or willfully ignorant (and some, racist).  The people who support the new method, or curriculum, generally seem to me to be humble, and interested in working through our country's issues.  I'll gladly read Kendi, but also McWhorter, or even Clarence Thomas, to help illuminate my understanding of the current experience of Black Americans.

@Matthew I'm not sure it's being taught in a way that necessarily tries to make kids feel guilt and traumatized.  I remember feeling guilty about being white when I learned about slavery.  I matured to understand it was not specifically "my fault" but that I needed to be realistic about what my ancestors did to other people.   Parents can help with that.

@eheck Find me someone, somewhere, outside of the Klan who says slavery and Jim Crow were "right."  No teacher does this.  And show me some hard evidence that to these parents "uncomfortable" means that teaching the rightness of slavery and Jim Crow makes them "comfortable."  This is the kind of condescending spin that drives parents, including African Americans concerned about what these concepts say about blacks, to the polls.

@MG You are making it sound as though these are new topics being explored, topics I learned about in school 50 years ago. It's not the subject matter, it's the indoctrination through a new, race-obsessed lens and the defenestration of MLK that's the problem.

@MG Sixty years ago, when I was in junior high, they showed us graphic photos of GIs burying dozens and dozens of naked, starved bodies in German concentration camps. We also studied in graphic detail the horrors of slavery and the massive hypocritical efforts of southern states to warp the constitutions to its will with fundamental compromises. Of course, this was in western NYS and they did conveniently pretend we had done all we could with the Civil War and it was up to the South to get its own act together. But nevertheless, history was not sugarcoated. And we were expected--in fact, assigned--to read conflicting versions of history as early as 8th grade. Getting real is nothing new. It's something to return to, after the grotesque politicization and dumbing-down of education over the past 50 years.

@MG And it's exactly because these things ARE taught but it still doesn't provide the desired impact that race extremists overreach. There's not much more mileage they can get out of merely teaching history. Instead they have to interpret the history we all plainly see into new fangled theories of white oppression to justify policies that try to reverse the effects of history with discrimination today. Their actual goals are quite simple, but they have to create complex theories because we would be shocked and horrified if they put it to us directly.

@MG   "In point of fact, both slavery and Jim Crow had the overwhelming support of white citizens and the muscular backing of the state."  Yes, but the important fact is that the confederates and the segregationists LOST, and America is better off for it.  The advocates of CRT choose to ignore this fact and instead portray white people and the United States as evil.

@Matthew 

Provide actual examples of this happening from reputable sources or it's fiction.

@MG I've been training social studies teachers for 17 years, and never ever have I encountered a single parent who longs for Jim Crow or who would stand silently in the crowd while whole populations are massacred (the Holocaust has nothing to do with this controversy over race in the schools).  Maybe there are a few die-hards in Ol' Miss, but your characterization of these parents is beyond the pale, and it's exactly why they're getting angrier.  See Sam Wineburg and Chauncey MonteSano's list of 10 Great Americans, published in the Journal of American History, where surveys of people on the street resulted in top 10 lists with Oprah Winfrey and Harriet Tubman at the very top, a direct outcome of the deep embedding of civil rights into state teaching practices -- civil rights education is the core of social studies and has been for almost 2 decades.  You can view the curricula of any state and see this.  Of course teachers can modify what they're told to teach, but you can't teach that master narrative by populating it with contented slaves, not by a long shot.
@Ajvan1 Nothing can ever change bigotry of the past. But I believe that bigotry in the US is waning. It is happening slowly,  and painfully so,  but it is occurring.

@MG 
Your students are lucky to have such a great teacher.
@Mmpack12 So, the people protesting at school board meetings at advocates of Critical Race Theory?

@MG 
My answer is the same one to those objecting to sex education in the schools; if you were teaching your own kids effectively they would already know all of this before they heard it at school. Parents with children finding race education uncomfortable are doing a lousy job raising their kids.

@MG I would bet you can't find 100 persons from a diverse group of Mississippian's who could pass your History class final exam. They don't know, and they don't care. Just don't rock their boat or punish anyone who cheats on the exam.

@C I don't need national pride. I am a child of God, and therefore, gloriously made. Similarly, if my country is doing great and wonderful things, I will be proud of it. Jingoistic pride is not helpful to anyone, anywhere.

@MG 

Teach it as history, not as a source of guilt for children born a century after the Civil War or a platform for pushing "systemic racism" as a significant issue today, because it isn't. It is just a rhetorical tool to drive Progressive fundraising and turnout.

@Shp    Here is what CRT is, more precisely, from a publication called Education Week:  "the theory says that racism is part of everyday life, so people—white or nonwhite—who don’t intend to be racist can nevertheless make choices that fuel racism."  IMHO there is a difference.  If you read a sentence out of context from Kendi's or Coates' books, you might sense that you are being accused; you need to read the whole book to hear what the author is saying.  If you think there might be a race problem in our country, why not take the time to really study another person's perspective?  Saying "not my fault", only, is not helpful.  It makes the problem worse.
@joe But, the confederates and segregationists didn't lose. The are all alive and well in the Republican party and they have won the war.

@Hideo Gump If you believe that, you must live in a different US than I see here  in rural Pennsylvania.  If a law were passed to prevent Black people from living and working in the area, it would have at least a 70% approval rate.
@Chris So well stated.

@MG  I am so happy I went to a school, a University, had parents who encouraged learning, real discussion and debate, walking in other's shoes, however uncomfortable the topic. Who believed learning about history and other people was a valuable lesson for life and humanity.

Does anyone who is against learning 'uncomfortable' topics ever think how far beyond 'uncomfortable' to outright terrifying and soul-destroying being a slave was (babies and children included), how awful it is to feel afraid in your own country purely because of your skin color, not be afforded the rights and respect that other citizens (white) take for granted (being on paper alone doesn't cut it, when it's the status quo).

@eheck 
Sad to say slavery and Jim Crow were wrong to some people, but profitable, and appropriate to many others. Tragically they still are.

@MG 
The good old days when white people could act with impunity are longed for by Republicans. They don't want to be reminded of the horrible things that were done on behalf of white supremacy. They just want those "great" old days back. Liars like Youngkin know that, so they just feed the beast.

@MG I don't have the answer either, but will note that my experience is that a section of this country is invested in denying its past and the effects of slavery.  My husband and I were on a tour of a plantation in S. Carolina a few years ago and were stunned to hear the tour guide say that "a change in the labor situation" caused the viability of the plantation to go down hill.  That was how he described the end of slavery.  We looked around and no one batted an eye.

@Chris 

I agree and fear it boils down to this. A focus on comfort is a focus on obedience. Soon it will be traumatizing to learn about climate change, traumatizing to learn about abuse by religious figures, traumatizing to learn about corporate or political misdeeds and too overwhelming to learn about atrocities of war. A shielded generation can then be exploited without resistance.

@Stewart Winger Better yet, instead of abolishing the textbook (that just turns the teacher into the textbook) *question* it.  Have students use primary sources to challenge its narrative and develop ideas of their own.  But this strategy is better tuned to high schools and above (maybe middle schoolers).  The real concern is the use of race-based groupings and frameworks for kids in the elementary grades who aren't equipped by experience or learning to question that approach or even to fully understand it.  In hose cases, race needs to be *in* the curriculum, but not *drive* the curriculum.
@ld My ancestors were still in Ireland until well after slavery was abolished, yet I am expected to feel guilty over what happened in the US back then? I think not.
@historian Not sugar-coated enough?

@MG 

BINGO!!!
The republican strategy has been to vest power in someone insignificant from an insignificant state who will always get elected - McConnell.
Once that power is secure, it's on to nonsense like this, more smokescreen, more division, more distraction.

@MG Teaching young people of appropriate age about the Holocaust doesn't come with the implication that your school buddy 3 desks over may have unconscious genocidal urges.

Until we figure out how to present life changing information without indicting half of the young & innocent, whose concept of power hasn't gone beyond being told to do their homework, with some form of permanent original sin of genocidal magnitude...

Let's just stipulate as reality that the mere idea of teaching these things in a country we seek to unite is insanity as a practical matter.

This isn't about denial, it's about being functional as individuals and society in our shared experience of being alive in the now.

Even amongst our closest loved ones whom have made mistakes, what happens if we don't forgive and instead dedicate our lives to reminding them every day at will about mistakes made in a past life so distant that many can't remember themselves?

Division & fighting is what will become of that relationship. Is it any great mystery why that same dynamic doesn't apply across the population? Especially when the topic itself divides many into tribes.

So instead of living in the here & now and SPECIFICALLY addressing/correcting bad, biased or unfair practices as a matter of universal rights, many are dragging Catholic level massive guilt trips into the picture.

If history is of interest, great. Most people don't care about history of any kind so demanding they care violates their life vision.

@eheck but you also were not taught that you are inherently racist by virtue of being white, which is literally part of the lesson in some schools. In fact it's become divisive simply to say "most white people aren't racist" as though it must be common knowledge that in fact all white people are at least a little bit racist...

The problem with that message is it leaves nowhere to go, all it accomplishes is turning off votes. There's a reason the extremities of CRT are turning off both white and minority voters. We need to seal the dam before it gets worse.

@eheck You were taught those things in a manly factual manner. Nowaday - white (and even asian kids) are flat out made to feel bad for simply their race.  And we have ALL seen this - so pretending this doesn't happen is a moot point.  The pandemic allowed TONS of parents to witness it with their own eyes.  The attacks on merit based admission to the top schools in Virginia flipped alot of Asians from D to R.  They don't want to ban the teaching of Civil Right history. They want the ideology of identity politics and CRT NOT in the classroom.

@Stewart Winger Maybe textbooks should just be required to word assertions with humility by attesting to nothing but what other sources say.  If citing sources is too advanced then maybe the subject is too advanced.

@Tim Europe was a "tribal" and primitive backwater not too long before it started patting itself on the back for being so advanced.  There was a sudden spurt of technological growth somewhere between Vikings and Columbus, and all it means is that technological advancement (1) spreads like wildfire (2) experiences cycles of quick and slow progress.  It so happened that Europe got into a market right before it ballooned, as it were, and also had a culture of aggression and greed ready to take full advantage fast.

@C 

What is wrong with telling the whole story?  Two chapters just won’t do it
@MG Tribal organization can coexist with states.

@MG i simply do not believe this is a common concern. I've been in this business for decades, produced dozens of modules on all the race related topics, never once encountered a teacher or a parent who objected. I don't doubt there are some. But they have nothing to do with the issue at hand now. CRT is in fact not about any of that. It is about shaming whites and patronizing minorities, and not much else.

@MG "Slavery and Jim Crow should make you uncomfortable because they are, in fact, uncomfortable."  Of course.  But notice that we avoid the things that make minorities feel uncomfortable.  It is not an equal playing field.  Europeans of the 1700s, with 2000+ years of history and achievement, did not think that tribal Africans were their "equals."  That idea would seem bizarre, totally lacking evidence.  There was no idea back then that we are all one single (abstract) "human race"-- tribal Africans, based on their behavior, their culture, were clearly inferior to Europeans.  Try including that historically accurate point of view in education.  You can't, because it is humiliating for minorities to face this truth.

@MG There’s a difference between teaching the facts of history, the good, the bad and the shades of gray, with sensitivity and nuance and using a sledgehammer to hit kids over the head on every page with a particular narrative favored by the sort of academics who push critical race theory and structural racism, etc., along with the message that being of European ancestry is an original sin staining their souls. People object to the latter.

comments.commentBody:
What the Virginia election clearly demonstrates is that we live in a country where a majority of it's citizens are more concerned over culture war issues than actual policy.

The next step for Democrats is to decide on how to respond to this reality. Do they roll in the mud with Republicans or do they change their policy message?

"maybe, the solution is for the party’s less-Trumpy constituencies to rally around on alternative whose electoral lib-owning just put Trump’s 2020 showing to shame."?

The dude only won by 2 points!

Left? What left? We have had good, maybe the historically best moderate leadership in Virginia for the last couple of administrations but once again bad party leadership runed it. We had a dynamic progressive gubernatorial candidate, Jennifer Carol Foy, a Black Woman with a good record who was shunted aside for the tepid, stiff big money democrat and former governor McAuliff. As ever, play-it-safe democrats fail to understand the important difference between primaries and elections and succumb to pressure from the part leaving democratic voters again with someone to vote against rather than for. Republicans were far more excited about their candidate and Black voters were not feeling mobilized by McAuliff. Candidates spoke in the coded partisan language of fear rather than on detailed issue agendas which could have made a difference as well.  Still, its close and al the votes are not yet counted

As Max Weber taught us, for every political affiliation, there are inconvenient facts, including Douthat's.  So I'd like to hear his response to what happened to my daughter, a middle-school history teacher in western Massachusetts.  After teaching a unit on African history, a parent called the principal to accuse her of being racist against white people.

Douthat mentions three theorists to support his that critical race theory is actually being taught in the schools.  That's the extent of his evidence of unsettling "ideas filtering into ... kids' classrooms in the last few years."  Maybe critical race theory and its penumbra is more than a boogeyman, but Douthat hasn't proved it.  He has presented flimsy argument with deficient empirical support.

As some of the comments here show, progressives will try to deflect blame and draw the wrong lessons from the GOP sweep in Virginia. They’ll point to the fact that the Dems’ candidate was an establishment, corporatist moderate. 

But you may have to live here in Virginia to realize how easily it was for Youngkin and the GOP to exploit some rhetorical slipups by McAuliffe and their broader disinformation campaign about CRT to winning effect. McAuliffe walked right into this culture war, which the GOP will ALWAYS win among the wider public, instead of neutralizing it. He also tried to paint Youngkin as Trump, which the latter easily parried by sounding normal and minimizing association with the orange-haired kakistocrat. 

If Dems let their progressive wing assert the wrong lessons from this, they will get swept next year.

I actually think Mr. Douthat is on to something. Even if parents in schools have never heard of Ibram X. Kendi or Robin DiAngelo, those ideas are filtering down to everyday people. Is there some outright racism involved in this backlash against progressivism? Of course, but two things can be true at once. There can be, on the one hand, an overreaction to teaching a more complicated history leading voters to reject Democratic platforms writ large, and on the other a legitimate argument that woke progressivism turns off even those people who are not card-carrying KKK members. The truth is that even though the Republican party has done very well at turning this into political victory in Virginia (and maybe more), Democrats have done very poorly at communicating that US history, for example, simply needs a fuller telling. At local levels, of course, politics is often more nuanced, but leadership at the top has got to find a way to communicate a more welcoming platform to people whose lives are simply too busy and anxious to deal with a kind of political message that mostly only academics and administrations at universities bathe in. You don't have to like this reality, but people do not want to be told they are inherently racist, which is what they're hearing.

This election just shows how incompetent the Democrats are. 
Policies to run on that are extremely popular:

Medicare for all
Free college tuition 
Vacation Law
Infrastructure Rebuild

But yet they keep on putting these Republican light democrats that run against these things. To win elections democrats need to stop running Joe Manchin and start running Bernie Sanders. We got schooled by a party with less people in it I don't understand how you have places like Arlington, Fairfax, and Richmond and still can't find a base to get out the vote.

We Democrats are terrible at messaging. 

Healthcare, the economy, job training, infrastructure, education and the environment are what the Democrats should be discussing. If cultural theorists are correct about the mechanics of structural racism in America, then we should expect that the mere mention of this fact will enrage those that benefit from structural racism. comments.commentBody:
What we are seeing on the national scene is not particularly a pushback against Democrats or their programs, but rather a more localized engagement and assertion through the vote of actual policy decisions that readily respond to popular preferences.  School boards, city and county councils, mayors, etc., are tangible and influenceable offices directly affected by one’s vote, and offers a one-to-one correlation with desired political, social, and even cultural ends.  
However, less so with state legislatures or governors, and most particularly with members of Congress — as is so glaringly obvious with all the toing-and-froing over the Biden proposals, where a vote to send a person to Congress in expectation of passage of desired legislation rarely comes to fruition.  Gerrymandering, Big Money, corporate lobbying, etc., etc., puts paid to the aspirations of voters.  And eventually, voters will say, why bother, what we want to see enacted as law won’t happen.  
But, passions remain high for ACTION, any action, and local elections — and issues framed about local concerns — will get the people out and usually get the desired result according to how the popular vote went.  And “what to teach our children” is a formidable incentive to vote, no matter how factitious or distorted the arguments that  are presented…vote THIS way, and changes are immediate.  And therein lies the crux of the matter.

The loss in Virginia falls on McAuliffe's shoulders. The big premise of this campaign was that Glenn Youngkin was a right-wing acolyte of Trump. McAuliffe was a successful governor, and could have easily focused on bread and butter issues that would have provided a counter narrative to Youngkin's messaging. But he didn't offer anything else beyond " I am not Trump." 

I will say this again, but Democrats, stop with the "we are not Trump messaging." It's clear that they need to offer vision beyond this one track messaging. Offer alternative and answers beyond the Republican's culture war messaging. A great start would be to campaign on bread and butter policy issues and to pass the infrastructure and social policy packages together. Get rid of the influences of the "woke" from social media and academia and present yourselves as rational policy-minded people. And perhaps you can avoid the bloodbaths of 2022 and 2024.

Instead, we see one expert after another that attempts to put angry parents in their place.  Any expert in tactical politics would advise the leader to sit, listen and thank the parents for their energy and commitment.  

Parents are never wrong, to a mature politician.  The principle of governance is the parents are rarely there.  If you make them angry, on a principle of all things (come on), the parents stay angry, and stay there, and you do not get back to governance. Yes, some people on the left use language that makes it easy for R's to inflame people, but the real lesson of Virginia is that Dems and the media have let R's get away with too many lies.

I am a National Board Certified High School English teacher. Through many years of working at both affluent and underserved high schools, I have forged a centrist position on "Critical Race Theory" over the past several years. Frankly, I never heard that term until a year ago, but DiAngelo and others have been used in education for many years now. 

As with all teaching tools, I sought aspects that worked for students and questioned others, while always reflecting on the strengths and limitations of my own perspective. 

The centering of race in secondary English classes has been good and bad. On one hand, I have seen students of color empowered to question and analyze texts; they do not simply accept the canon because it's the canon. On the other hand, I often see the joy of reading sapped away for all involved. Of course, the loss of reading joy is a nexus point for lots of change in America. 

My broader question as a teacher and citizen is, What should we teach? If the idea is that critique will lead to more fairness, then let's frame it that way. When Common Core started years ago, the argument was relevance in the workplace. That argument in 2021 oddly sounds anachronistic. For better or worse, I increasingly find literature and discussion to be a refuge from the world's madness, and my students agree. Thus, whether it's Alice Walker or Ernest Hemingway, reading acts as shelter for my students, a shelter to keep cool in a heating world.

Ross is right in this column about CRT and the Democrats needing to either defend it or to abandon it.  I went to law school from 1991 to 1994 at the University of Virginia.  Critical race theory was then being openly espoused and examined in law school curricula, including at UVA.  It was fringe theory then, and on the merits it deserved to remain so.  It had some, but not a lot, of explanatory value.  But it had (and has) very little positive policy implications for a nation governed by a Constitution with the 14th Amendment and that has laws and regulations seeking to make race irrelevant.  Yet it has now seeped out of rarified academic circles, and it does no good for Democrats to say "it isn't being taught in Virginia" when the DOE recommends CRT materials throughout its own website.  Those in favor of CRT need to defend it on the merits if they think they can.

The rest of the state, more rural, red.  I honestly think it's because they don't get much of the detail about what the GOP is actually doing.  Small town newspapers don't publish it, either because the owners are GOP or because they don't want to alienate any readers.  Many don't have cable.  
I spoke recently with a friend who, with her family, raises cattle on their farm in southern Virginia. I mentioned the new Texas abortion law and - seriously - she didn't know what I was talking about.

I think parents (voters) were traumatized by the visual  of the man being dragged out of the school board meeting -bloody- by security guards, as the Board sat there and flatly denied his daughter was assaulted by a trans student in the girls’ bathroom. 

I told a personal story in a reply to comment here . My husband was working on a construction site at a SUNY campus. The campus officials told the construction crews what restroom to use. It was the same gender -neutral restroom that eight- year-old girls attending a summer camp there were also using.  But the men didn’t know until they entered the bathroom. Some left, others didn’t. 

These gender -neutral bathrooms were forced upon us because a tiny percentage our population might feel uncomfortable.  I am not sure if a trans person ever used that bathroom, but that day male construction workers and young girls were in stalls next to one another. My husband was horrified and came home and said “is this REALLY what they want??”

This is just so wrong. Give us our bathrooms back.

replies.commentBody: Gender neutral bathrooms can be positive. I traveled through airports across the country with my young son a couple months ago and struggled to find family bathrooms or gender neutral bathrooms. I felt uncomfortable sending him into the men’s restroom but knew he was too old to go into the women’s restroom with me. This would not have been an issue if my husband could travel with us, but I feel for all the single parents who find themselves in similar situations.

comments.commentBody: It was an election decided as much by misguided Democrats as uninformed Republicans demanding authority without accountability and casting themselves, yet again, as defenders of freedom, and Democrats made it look easy.

The “technicalities” that the Democratic candidate fell back on, as you put it, are otherwise known as “facts”, aka, the truth. In real life, critical race theory is not taught in public schools with any regularity, and it’s clear that the author is aware of this fact.  That’s not a technicality, it’s  reality, something in severely short supply in the manufactured world of fear fostered by the right in order to maintain some semblance of power in a changing world. Be honest, Ross.

Republicans win by leveraging deflection and stoking fear. Critical race theory, while an important topic, won't be top of mind when large areas of the country are without clean drinking water and/or dealing with the onslaught of increasingly catastrophic natural disasters. Or dealing with more severe political violence. It's amazing how easily we're distracted from the more urgent and consequential issues threatening all of us, regardless of race or party.

There's always a battle between the forces of a revanchist reactionary ideology and a forward-leaning progressive ideology in this country. That has been the basis of the political battleground from the founding of the country.

That ideological battleground  grew so intense that a literal battleground was the place where the tension between these forces once met.
 Slavery was repudiated. Jim Crow was repudiated. Ruthless robber barons were repudiated. Workers rights were defended with the union movement, civil rights were defended, and on and on.

We just have to recognize these two opposing forces are the enduring definition of the ongoing debate that will never end in this country.

But by any measure, over the long run, the forces of a progressive ideology have brought whatever improvement in our society that has endured.

These small skirmishes cannot obscure the progress that has occurred and will continue to occur as long as people engage in the fight for a more decent society.

So, rest up, relax, reflect and take the long view. We are winning in the long run.
We have defeated revanchism and reactionary movements before and we will continue to do so.
Don't lose heart.

Democrats just consistently fail to either acknowledge or recognize that the issues are not fiscal, but social. They’ll continue to see these defeats until they dial it back a bit. You want it all?  You can’t have it all.
